content: this is dmg we'll add your biological and technological distinctiveness to our
arm we're making an acid pool acid pool and not a silly fool
okay so we're making an acid pool this is going to be relatively simple and
we're just going to use the hole we used in video 4d and I'm going to use the
tracing we did in video 41 spike put trap that's it there and I'm going to
trace out another circle from a piece of cardstock and we've cut that out and put
it in the hole so this is going to be a reusable hole which you're gonna be able
to take the acid out and put it back in whenever you need it
so this hole can be used for a multitude of different purposes so use a spike pit
trap already and now we're going to use it for an acid pool so then you're gonna
place a sheet of grease paper that's gonna be larger than the hole itself
over the hole and then push the cardboard that you've cut out down into
the bottom and curved the baking paper over the rim of the hole and push that
card stock down into the bottom as far as it'll go so now I'm just adding some
green paint and I'm using a brush to just paint at the bottom of the pit over
the card stock and all out the sides to just below the rim of the hole and now
I'm just adding hot glue so I'm just gonna add hot glue in a circle and just
keep going around in circles circles all the way around now the key to this if
the cardboard warps a little bit it may rise up so you just push it back down
best thing to do is to leave some gaps between the rings so though the hot glue
should be quite hot when you do this and leave the gaps as you're doing rings
around so the hot glue will flow into itself and it will start to form bubbles
where those air gaps were so those bubbles eventually are going to harden
and give you a sort of bubble look and on the beginning there's a lot more
bubbles because the hot glue is hot bells start to pop and melt into one
another but in the end there will be more bubbles left over so it doesn't
matter if it looks like there's too many bubbles in the beginning that's
perfectly fine you do also find this effect if you're coming to the end of a
glue stick you also find it starts to bubble
so you could also do that at an end of a burglar stick and then just continue to
fill glue around the edges and that will flow into the middle and if there's any
sort of glaring gaps fill them in because you'll want it to be quite flat
and you know just around the edges is important so you don't want to go over
the edge I'm just going to go up to the edge up to where the green paint is and
the green paint basically will shine through and that's what makes it look
like the acid pool here I'm just leaving it for time in time-lapse so you can
just see it drop hardening if you want you can actually pull cold water over
this put it under a cold tap it will harden a lot faster but you do want to
let it harden a little bit first because you don't want the running water to
create different warp effects on the top of the water not the top of the acid so
now I've just taken the the acid out of the hole and I'm peeling off the grease
paper just quite ill eclis but it does come off quite easily now the paint
under they will still be wet so just be careful you don't want to get paint over
everything now the green that you see underneath is
either the back of that cardboard that I used was green so it's not the paint
looking underneath that's just what the backing colour was I'm just cutting off
all the excess wisps and things like that but I'm not cleaning the edge so
it'll still look like it's lapping up against the edges of the hole I'm just
placing it on some paper towel just to allow time for the green paint to dry
and that's it just stick straight back into the hole and it fits really nice
and snug that won't fall out at all you have to pop it out and there it is on
the tile and as you can see the bubbles coming up from the bottom that looks
